text: <extra_id_0> Basic Fibroblast Growth Factor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> Promotes Necroptosis in L929 Cells
It has been established that mouse fibrosarcoma L929 cells undergo necroptotic cell death following stimulation with <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 10 ] , [ 17 ] .

In addition , inhibition of <extra_id_0> caspase-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity alone , either through siRNA knockdown or by using the pan-caspase inhibitor , zVAD.fmk , is sufficient to trigger necroptosis in these cells [ 10 ] , [ 14 ] .

Interestingly , while necroptosis was initially identified as a back - up form of cell death triggered by pro-apoptotic stimuli in the presence of apoptosis inhibitors [ 17 ] , recent analysis of physiological cell death during mouse development has suggested that the loss of apoptotic regulators , such as <extra_id_0> caspase-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> FADD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 18 ] , [ 19 ] , [ 20 ] , leads to robust induction of necroptosis and death of E10.5 embryos even though apoptosis is not normally induced in wild type embryos .

These data are reminiscent of the observations in L929 cells where the loss of caspase activity in healthy cells is sufficient to trigger necroptosis and prompted us to explore the extrinsic or intrinsic cellular factors that promote necroptosis once <extra_id_0> caspase-8 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity , which cleaves and inactivates <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase and the <extra_id_0> RIP1 deubiquitinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> <extra_id_0> CYLD <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> [ 21 ] , [ 22 ] , is removed in L929 cells .
Consistent with a previous report [ 16 ] , we found that serum starvation of L929 cells prevented necroptosis in response to zVAD.fmk ( Fig . 1A ) .
The addition of growth factors , such as <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , restored zVAD.fmk induced death under serum free conditions ( Fig . 1B ) .

Interestingly , this does not reflect a generic requirement for growth factor signaling , as only some growth factors ( <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IGF-1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not <extra_id_0> EGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and PDGF ) promoted death ( Fig . 1B ) .
Furthermore , growth factor - dependent necroptosis required the inhibition of caspase activity , as <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> alone did not induce cell death ( Fig . 1C ) .

In contrast , <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> triggered necroptosis equally efficiently in the absence of serum ( Fig . 1A ) , suggesting that either growth factors and zVAD.fmk or <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> are required for necroptotic death in L929 cells .
Previously we described the development of 7-Cl-O-Nec-1 ( Nec-1 ) as a potent and selective inhibitor of <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase and necroptosis ( Fig .
Recently , its selectivity has been further validated against a panel of more than 400 human kinases [ 15 ] .
This inhibitor efficiently blocked growth factor / zVAD .

fmk - induced necroptosis under serum free conditions in L929 cells and both zVAD.fmk and <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced necroptosis under full serum conditions ( Fig . 1B , S1B ) .
To further validate the role of <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , we used an inactive analog , 7-Cl-O-Nec-1i ( Nec-1i ) ( Fig .
S1A ) , which contains an extra N-methyl group that leads to almost complete loss of <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase inhibitory activity in vitro [ 23 ] .
Nec-1i was unable to protect L929 cell death under serum condtions treated with zVAD.fmk or <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Fig .
S1B ) or serum free conditions treated with <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> / zVAD.fmk ( Fig .
S1C ) .
This confirms that <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase is responsible for necroptosis in L929 cells under both serum and serum free conditions .
We next examined whether <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> contributes to zVAD.fmk - induced necroptosis under normal serum conditions ( 10 % FBS ) .

We used two <extra_id_0> bFGF receptor tyrosine kinase <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibitors ( PD173074 and PD166866 ) , and determined that inhibition of <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> signaling strongly inhibited zVAD.fmk - induced necroptosis under normal serum conditions ( Fig . 1D ) .

In contrast , neither <extra_id_0> bFGF receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> inhibitor was able to attenuate <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - induced necroptosis ( Fig . 1D ) , consistent with growth factors being dispensable for this pathway ( Fig . 1A ) .
Overall , these data suggest that the induction of necroptosis by zVAD.fmk is promoted by <extra_id_0> bFGF <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> under both serum and serum free conditions .
The induction of necroptosis , however , is not a simple consequence of growth factor signaling since not all growth factors allowed death to occur .
Instead , specific signaling events mediated by particular growth factors appear to contribute to necroptotic death .
